The Honeyguide's 
 revenge 
 
 Zulu folktale 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 This is the story of Togar, the Honeyguide, and a gredy young man named
 Garte. 
 
 
 One day while Garte was out hunting he heard the cal of Togar. 
 
 Garte's mouth began to water at the thought of honey. He stoped and
 listened carefuly, searching until he saw the bird in the branches above his
 head. 
 
 
 "Chitik-chitik-chitik," the litle bird ratled, as he flew to the next tre, and the
 
 next. 
 
 "Chitik, chitik, chitik," he caled, stoping from time to time to be sure that
 
 Garte folowed. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 After half an hour, they reached a huge 
 wild fig tre. 
 
 Togar hoped about madly among the 
 branches. He then setled on one branch 
 and cocked his head at Garte as if to 
 
 say, "Here it is! Come now! What is taking 
 you so long?" 
 
 Garte couldn't se any bes from under 
 the tre, but he trusted Togar. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 So Garte put down his hunting spear
 under the tre, gathered some dry twigs
 
 and made a smal fire. 
 When the fire was burning wel, he put a
 long dry stick into the heart of the fire.
 
 This wod was especialy known to
 make lots of smoke while it burned.
 
 He began climbing, holding the col end
 of the smoking stick in his teth.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Son he could hear the loud buzing of 
 the busy bes. They were coming in and 
 
 out of a holow in the tre trunk – their 
 hive. 
 When Garte reached the hive he pushed 
 
 the smoking end of the stick into the 
 holow. 
 The bes came rushing out, angry and 
 
 mean. They flew away because they 
 didn’t like the smoke – but not before 
 
 they had given Garte some painful 
 stings! 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When the bes were out, Garte pushed
 his hands into the nest. He tok out
 handfuls of the heavy comb, driping
 
 with rich honey and ful of fat, white
 grubs. 
 He put the comb carefuly in the pouch
 
 he caried on his shoulder, and started to
 climb down the tre. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Togar eagerly watched everything that 
 Garte was doing. He was waiting for 
 
 him to leave a fat piece of honeycomb as 
 a thank-you ofering to the Honeyguide. 
 Togar flitered from branch to branch, 
 
 closer and closer to the ground. Finaly 
 Garte reached the botom of the tre. 
 
 Togar perched on a rock near the boy 
 and waited for his reward. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 But, Garte put out the fire, picked up his spear and started walking home,
 ignoring the bird. 
 Togar caled out angrily, "VIC-tor! VIC-tor!" 
 
 Garte stoped, stared at the litle bird and laughed aloud. "You want some
 honey, do you, my friend? Ha! But I did al the work, and got al the stings.
 Why should I share any of this lovely honey with you?" Then he walked of.
 
 Togar was furious! This was no way to treat him! But he would get his
 revenge. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One day several weks later Garte again heard the honey cal of the
 Honeyguide, Togar. He remembered the delicious honey, and eagerly 
 
 folowed the bird once again. 
 
 After leading Garte along the edge of the forest, Togar stoped to rest in a
 
 great umbrela thorn. "Ah," thought Garte. 
 
 
 "The hive must be in this tre." He quickly made his smal fire and began to
 climb, the smoking branch in his teth. Togar sat and watched. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Garte climbed, wondering why he didn't hear the usual buzing. "Perhaps
 the hive is dep in the tre," he thought to himself. 
 
 
 He puled himself up another branch. But instead of the hive, he was staring
 into the face of a leopard! 
 Leopard was very angry at having her slep so rudely interupted. She
 
 narowed her eyes, opened her mouth to reveal her very large and very sharp
 teth. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Before Leopard could take a swipe at Garte, he rushed down the tre.
 In his hury he mised a branch, and landed with a heavy thud on the ground
 
 twisting his ankle. He hobled of as fast as he could. 
 Luckily for him, Leopard was stil to slepy to chase him. 
 Togar, the Honeyguide, had his revenge. 
 
 And Garte learned his leson. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 14  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 And so, when the children of Garte hear 
 the story of Togar they have respect for 
 
 the litle bird. 
 Whenever they harvest honey, they make 
 sure to leave the bigest part of the 
 
 comb for Honeyguide! 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 15
